div1.p: Jackson lists all the properties that make up the Post of Columbia Barracks, along with their rental information. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from Harry Frederick Jackson to Chauncey B. Baker, January 17, 1901
div1.opener:
file
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA.
Office of Assistant Engineer.
Quemados, January 17, 1901.
Major Chauncey B. Baker,
Chief Quartermaster,
Department of Cuba.
SIR:-
div1.p:
Replying to your letter of the 10th instant (Reference #3879),
I have the honor to inform you that rent was last paid Tomasa
Cardenas, deceased, to include June 30, 1900, by Captain H. J.
Slocum, Disbursing Officer for the Department of Havana and Pinar
del Rio. On that date the accounts were transferred by Captain
Slocum to the Chief Quartermaster of that Department, and his office
informs me that no rents have been paid since that time.

Referring to the second paragraph of your letter, the following
is a list of the parcels of land comprised within the limits of the
Post of Columbia Barracks, together with names of owners and amounts
of rentals. I cannot give you the date on which last payment was
made, as this was done by the Chief Quartermaster of the Department,
or by the Disbursing Officer of the Department. He can probably
give you the desired information.

First.- The parcel marked “Benitez” on enclosed map - should be
marked “Barreto” - contains thirty two (32) acres; is owned by
Doña Maria de la Salud de Benitez, a resident of San Antonio #32-1/2,
Guanabacoa; amount of rent twenty (20) dollars per month. Copy of
lease furnished Captain Slocum, and by him forwarded to you.
Parcel 1

Second.- “Buena Vista” -- The portion within the Post of Col-
umbia Barracks is that part of the farm lying to the northwest of
the Marianao railroad. This portion contains about sixty six (66)
acres, is owned by Frank Montros, #35 Mercaderes, Havana; monthly
rental forty (40) dollars. Copy of this lease was furnished Captain
Slocum, and by him forwarded to you.
Parcel 5

Third.- “El Recreo de las Tres Rosas”-- Portion northwest of
the Marianao railroad is within the post of Columbia Barracks. This
portion contains approximately one hundred (100) acres; is owned by
Manuel Nogueira, present address not known - somewhere in Havana -
attorney, Major Runcie; no lease, as owner refused to lease land
since March 1, 1900 (?), at amount allowed by board of officers.
It is understood that claim for rent and damages has been forwarded
to Washington.
Parcel 6

Fourth.- Portion marked “Onina y Sitio San Antonio” - correct
name of this property is “Larrazabal”; portion northwest of the
railroad is within the limits of the Post of Columbia Barracks.
This portion contains approximately seventeen (17) acres, is owned
by the Sociedad Economica de Amigos del Pais, of which Alfredo Zayas
was president. This farm is leased by Melchor Bautista, and sub-
leased by him to Pedro F. Diago. Rent was last paid on the portion
of the land within the Post to José M. Callejas, Galiano #50,
Havana. This man leased from Diago the portion referred to, but
was ordered off by the Military Authorities, and the land taken
possession of by them. Rent since that date which seems to be due
Diago has not yet been paid. I enclose herewith under separate
envelopes correspondence relating to this subject. This tract of
land is one of those mentioned in your letter of recent date to
Parcel 11
(3)
Captain H. J. Slocum. Monthly rental agreed to, seventeen (17)
dollars Spanish gold.

Fifth.- The Farm “Jesus Maria” -- Portion lying to the north-
west of the Marianao Railroad is within the limits of the Post of
Columbia Barracks. This portion contains approximately eighty
eight (88) acres, is owned by the Condesa Caledonia del Val, whose
agent is Juan F. Urribari, Mercaderes 29, Havana; sub-leased by Juan
Guerra, who resides upon the place. Lease for portion forming a
part of Columbia Barracks has been made between Urribari, as the
agent for the owner, Juan Guerra, the lessee, and the Military
Government of the Island of Cuba, and forwarded to your office for
signature. It is presumed that the matter was concluded in that
office. The monthly rental specified was forty five (45) dollars.
Parcel 10

Sixth.- “Sitio la Serafina” -- Portion lying to the northwest
of the Marianao Railroad is within the limits of the Post of
Columbia Barracks. Portion lying to the south of the Marianao
Railroad is controlled by the Military Authorities in so far as
the sale of intoxicants and the establishment of houses of prostitu-
tion is concerned. Farm contains thirty three (33) acres; is owned
by José Dominguez y Lomus, Calzada Real #64, Quemados; leased by
Government for fifteen (15) dollars per month. Copy of lease was
given Captain Slocum, and by him forwarded to you.
Parcel 8

Seventh.- Farm marked “Hipodromo”, properly called “Las Hornos
y Anona”. Farm contains sixty six (66) acres, of which an irregular
shaped piece containing [unclear] forty (40) acres is leased by the
Government, and balance of farm controlled by the Government in so
far as sale of intoxicants and establishment of houses of prostitu-
Parcel 9
(4)
tion is concerned; owned by Salvador Hernandez, who lives on the
place; monthly rental (50) fifty dollars. [unclear]Owner refused to execute
lease, but has regularly accepted fifty (50) dollars per month, for
[unclear]rent, which is amount allowed by board.

Eighth.- “La Gomera” (the one nearest the town of Quemados) -
This farm contains thirty three (33) acres, is owned by the Marianao
Railroad; monthly rental, twenty (20) dollars. Copy of lease
delivered to Captain Slocum and by him forwarded to you.
Parcel 7

Ninth.- Farm “Padre” -- Owner not known, no lease has been
executed.

Tenth.- Farm marked “Tuscano” -- It is believed that this is
improperly marked so on the map, and that it should be marked
“Vista Hermosa”, which is shown on the map as the next piece of
property. This farm is claimed by R. O. Williams of the North
American Trust Company. He stated to me, however, that he would
prefer not to have any rent from it if it necessitated his looking
up his deeds. This piece of land is referred to in your letter of
recent date to Captain Slocum.
2
Parcel 12

Eleventh.- “La Gomera” (the one farthest from the town of
Quemados) -- Contains thirty three (33) acres, all in the Post of
Columbia Barracks; is owned by Doña Aña Callejas y Armenteros, power
of attorney held by Carlos Callejas, #11 Tajadillo, Havana; monthly
rental, ten (10) dollars. Copy of lease was delivered to Captain
Slocum, and forwarded by him to you.
Parcel 4

Twelfth.- A portion of the farms “[unclear]”“Magulles” and “San Armas” --
The portion within the Post of Columbia Barracks contains about
forty five (45) acres; is owned by Rufino Otamendi, #19 General Lee
Street, Quemados. It is believed that rent for this farm was
Parcel 3
(5)
paid Mr. Otamendi for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1900, at the
rate of thirty (30) dollars per month. On that date he violated
his agreement to renew his lease for as long as the Government
desired, and has since then refused thirty (30) dollars per month.
He has a claim against the Government for rent of farm and de-
struction of a certain field of hennequen, which has already been
adjudicated.
Parcel 3

Thirteenth.- Portion of the farm “San Augustin”, “San Antonio”,
or “San Basilio” -- This is the property of the late Tomasa Cardenas
which has been referred to in previous correspondence.
Parcel 2

Fourteenth.- Portion of land near La Playa de Marianao
occupied as Military Cemetery -- This land is leased for a period
of ninety nine (99) years, and payment in full for that time has
been made. The owner has agreed to deliver to the Military Govern-
ment or its successor a deed to the property at any time within the
period of ninety nine years that it shall be asked of him, without
extra compensation. A copy of this lease was forwarded to Division
Headquarters.

Copies of all of these leases which have been forwarded to you
are on file among my papers. They can be copied if necessary, but
it is thought that you have copies of every one which I have made.

Referring to the third paragraph of your letter, I have to say
that I have sent to you the only map which we at present have of
this property. I am having a map of the Post of Columbia Barracks
made, and will show upon that map the property leased. When it is
completed I shall be pleased to send you a blue print if you desire
it.

If I can give you any further information in regard to this
matter, I shall be very glad to have you let me know.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, H.J. Jackson 1st Lieutenant, 2nd Artillery,
ASSISTANT ENGINEER
